question: 5 (c)
sols_html:
To find \(b^\perp\) we take the project of b onto the null space \(u_3\) from part b

\(proj_{u_3}=(u_3\cdot b)u_3\)

\(=\frac{1}{ 3} (\begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\cdot \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 3\\ 4 \end{bmatrix})\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\)

We can find \(b^\parallel\) by vector addition

\(b-b^\perp = b^\parallel\)

\(=\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 3\\ 4 \end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 4\\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\)

\(b^\parallel =\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 4\\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\)

\(b^\perp =\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\)
sols_latex:
To find $b^\perp$ we take the project of b onto the null space $u_3$
from part b

$proj_{u_3}=(u_3\cdot b)u_3$

$=\frac{1}{ 3} (\begin{bmatrix}
1 & -1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\cdot \begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3\\
4
\end{bmatrix})\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}$

We can find $b^\parallel$ by vector addition

$b-b^\perp = b^\parallel$

$=\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3\\
4
\end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
4\\
3
\end{bmatrix}$

$b^\parallel =\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
4\\
3
\end{bmatrix}$

$b^\perp =\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}$
sols_raw:
To find <math>b^\perp</math> we take the project of b onto the null space <math>u_3</math> from part b

<math>proj_{u_3}=(u_3\cdot b)u_3</math>

<math>=\frac{1}{ 3} (\begin{bmatrix}
1 & -1 & 1
\end{bmatrix}\cdot \begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3\\
4
\end{bmatrix})\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}</math>

We can find <math>b^\parallel</math> by vector addition

<math>b-b^\perp = b^\parallel</math>

<math>=\begin{bmatrix}
2\\
3\\
4
\end{bmatrix}-\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
4\\
3
\end{bmatrix}</math>

<math>b^\parallel =\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
4\\
3
\end{bmatrix}</math>

<math>b^\perp =\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
1
\end{bmatrix}</math>
statement_html:
A matrix A and a vector b are given by

\(\displaystyle A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\)

\(\displaystyle b = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}\)

Split b into \(b= b^\perp +b^\parallel\), where \(b^\parallel\) is in R(A) and \(b^\perp\) is in \(R(A)^\perp\) (i.e. the orthogonal complement of R(A).)
statement_latex:
A matrix \emph{A} and a vector \emph{b} are given by

$\displaystyle A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$

$\displaystyle b = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}$

Split b into $b= b^\perp +b^\parallel$, where $b^\parallel$ is in R(A)
and $b^\perp$ is in $R(A)^\perp$ (i.e. the orthogonal complement of
R(A).)
statement_raw:
A matrix ''A'' and a vector ''b'' are given by

<math> \displaystyle A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}</math>

<math> \displaystyle b = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}</math>

Split b into <math>b= b^\perp +b^\parallel</math>, where <math>b^\parallel</math> is in R(A) and <math>b^\perp</math> is in <math>R(A)^\perp</math> (i.e. the orthogonal complement of R(A).)
